segments.text: students and professors back in the early 1920s?
Well, I think we had lots of, there was lots more personal contact.
You knew them much more intimately, and they knew the students intimately.
There was, now there's so many that it's come
more difficult to know much about your students.
At least it was getting that way when I wound up out there.
And I think probably back yonder we had much more respect for our instructors and professors than they have now.
because, well, it's just the trend of the times.
I guess they don't have the respect for the parents that they used to have.
That is— So you think that your idea then is that this is a generalization from the home?
Yeah, that's right.
Do you think there's other factors why they don't seem to have more or as much respect today for their professors as they used to?
Well, I think they're taught children these days are more or less trained not to have too much respect.
We never thought of calling anybody by their first name.
You never thought of calling a professor by his first name?
Yes.
And if he had a title, we used that.
But now they'll introduce any old gray-headed guy as Joe Bloke.
There seems to be a feeling of equality that didn't used to exist.
You can go to some of the Latin country and Mexico's and they have much more respect down there when they're addressing people like that.
I was wondering about just out of class relations between students and professors also back in the early 1920s.
Did you ever have any social events with professors?
Did people ever get together and
Oh, have intramural softball games or, I don't know, drink a beer together or anything like that.
No.
No, they didn't.
Now, with small departments, sometimes the department head would have the seniors in for supper, for dinner sometime before they graduated, but there'd be maybe not more than a dozen
sometimes three or four, depending on the size of the senior class in that particular department.
But, and a lot of the, sometimes they'd have, well, the students would have RV ball and senior ball and all that sort of stuff, and a good many of the professors would come to that if they cared to.
They were certainly invited.
But as far as
Well, we didn't have any beer joints around here then.
Nobody was doing prohibition.
That's absolutely right.
So there wasn't any, because Cindy had no fraternizing of that type during that time.
Okay.
Let's move on to talk about personalities here for a moment.
Of course, the most predominant personality at the time is Dr. Mark Francis, and he was your professor.
Would you describe him?
What kind of character was he?
Well, he was very pleasant, and he was hard of hearing, so you didn't talk to him.
He did the talking.
Oh, I see.
And he just carried on from there, but he was very pleasant, a little short fella, always in a hurry, and a wonderful lecturer.
He wasn't a taskmaster.
What do you mean?
He didn't give you any homework or many quizzes or anything of that nature.
He gave you the lectures and you're supposed to remember it, and that was it.
So he wasn't hard in that respect, but
He did a wonderful job of preparing the cadavers for dissection.
Probably did too good a job, made it too easy, because he'd inject the veins with one color of blue plastiparas, and he'd inject the arteries with red, and then you could just follow them out.
Whereas ordinarily, you just have a collapsed
blood vessel there and you have to figure out what it is.
But his were easy to follow out and dissect.
They did a good job.
Dr. Dunn, as far as his lectures were concerned,
He gave the best lecture of anyone in the veterinary school, best organized.
And he'd have it boiled down to essentials.
Good speaker?
Good speaker, yes.
And he was great.
What kind of man was he?
What do you mean, what kind of man?
Well, I mean, could you describe him?
Well, he was very pleasant.
He was short, not very tall, he was a little taller than Dr. Francis and rather stout and well he was very pleasant.
How about Grady?
How was he on Grady?
Could you compare him with Dr. Francis on Grady?
Oh yes, he was better at that than Dr. Francis.
Better in which way?
In that he'd give you a little more, work you a little more.
Oh, I see.
You'd have to work a little harder to earn your grade from him.
Dr. Leonard was a great man.
He was, if anything, he was too modest to get national recognition.
He was a better, I'd say, surgeon in many respects than lots of the people that wrote textbooks, but he wasn't interested in that sort of thing, in recognition.
He wanted to do his job, and he was an excellent surgeon.
So he taught the course on surgery?
Eventually.
Now Dr. Marsteller did first, and then Dr. Leonard did.
Could you talk about Dr. Marsteller?
Dr. Marsteller was, he was a peculiar sort of individual.
He'd try to make you mad.
To get you to do things, respond.
How would he try to get you mad?
Could you give me an example?
I can't give you an example, but
He'd make you do things that were useless.
Just menial things to knock you down.
And he was worse with his student labor and his secretaries that way than he was with the students, I guess, that he taught.
and he was always collecting things.

At one time they were feeding hogs the garbage from the mess hall and he had the project and he'd have a man going through all that garbage, getting all the forks and spoons and things that had been thrown in the garbage
And he had a room and he had them all stuck away there.
And he had all kinds of junk around.
They told a story one time that he was going across the campus and he saw a wheelbarrow out there.
He said, somebody's going to steal that.
So he threw it in his car and took it down there and put it in the basement of the veterinary hospital.
Probably belonged to some maintenance man.
Probably did.
But he didn't think somebody was going to steal that, and so he took it.
But he was always, he'd have workmen that gathered lumber, and he'd have them knocking the nails out and straightening the nails.
He was, I don't know what it is, what kind of quirk you'd call it, he just couldn't stand it and see anything go to waste.
And he was always doing something like that.
But he was generous at his
If you went out with him, if you were doing something with him, or you went on a call with him, or went on a trip with him, he'd pay everything.
He was generous, but he couldn't stand to see junk go to waste.
Maybe he was melting all that silver down and cashing it in.
Now it would be quite valuable today.
I don't know what became of all that stuff.
I guess they threw it away when they tore the old veterinary hospital down.
The old veterinary hospital was a little frame building.
It was

Well there's a little building there and at the end of it by there used to be a museum and originally that was the whole cholera laboratory and the old veterinary hospital was just the other side of that not too far from there.
I'm still interested in Dr. Francis do you
Have any more thoughts on him?
Well, he was always, he was very observant.
He didn't miss anything.
As I say, he did the talking.
I remember I was going to one cold morning, must have been about this time of year, frost was on the ground.
And I was living over in what they called
Beta Hall then.
There were two frame buildings that used to be, well at one time they were kind of hotels, and then they made them into dormitories for civilian students.
I'd graduated, so I was living in Beta Hall, and I was going to the, over to anatomy, and the anatomy building is, was there by
close to the textile building, if you know where the textile building is.
Anyway, there was a water tower there, a great big water tower.
That's not there anymore.
And this boy had jumped off the water tower during the night, and he was laying there, had frost on him.
Dr. Francis came out of the anatomy building, came over and looked at him,
Says, huh, bad medicine, one drop to the dose.
And he had lots of expressions like that.
If he wanted to talk about somebody who was pompous, he'd say, Colonel Big Belly came along on his horse and never batted an eye on him.
But he had lots of...
He had a good sense of humor.
Oh, yeah, wonderful.
And he had lots of little expressions like that.
I remember one time we were in anatomy there.
He was skeleton of the horse.
He had a skeleton of a horse there.
And he was talking about the joints, different joints.
And then he got to the hip joint.
He looked at the thing.
He kind of closed his eyes and pointed, and he said, Ha!
That's one place where the good Lord could have made an improvement.
That's the hip joint.
So he was sharp.
Gee, he was sharp.
I remember he was always collecting mastodon bones and whatnot.
And he had this skeleton, not a skeleton, but a skull.
I guess it must have been of a mastodon.
It was about that behind.
And he had all the parts of it.
And he brought a man in from New York or somewhere to put it together for him.
And the guy was standing there and he had this little
piece of bone and he was looking at it and looking at the skull.
Dr. Francis came sashaying by there.
He says, hop, I think you'll find that goes here.
Oh, he was sharp.
Students must have liked him then.
Oh yeah, they loved him.
He was hard of hearing and lots of times his classes were pretty noisy.
Could he answer questions or was he too hard of hearing to hear questions?
He didn't ask questions.
Oh you didn't ask questions in his class?
He covered everything.
Oh I see.
I know you were a student then and he was the administrator but did
Did it seem like, from the student's angle, that the job of administration was well done?
Yes, as far as we could tell, administration was all right.
He didn't like administration.
I don't think he liked going up there with the brass to the academic council meetings and things.
But yes, he was a good administrator.
Okay, let's turn to the vet program itself when you were there.
What did you think, did you think that there were some particularly strong points of the program when you went through and some that were weak?
I think the strongest parts were over in the clinical subjects.
You know, clinical subjects and in the practice.
In other words, training the students for field work.
Yes.
That's probably, I think, one of the strongest points.
But it's hard to compare it because you had these other basic courses that you had to have before you got to that.
And if you didn't understand them, well, you didn't understand your clinical work.
but I think they were all pretty strong when I was there.
You felt when you left in 1926 to go into private practice in New Orleans that you had been well trained?
Yes.
Now you left in 1926 and then you returned in 1937, 11 years.
You must have, when you came back, you must have noticed a few changes.
Could you describe those?
Well, it was lots of, as far as the physical plant was concerned, they had done lots of building during the Depression.
See, I wasn't there during the Depression.
Right, right, I know.
Then they had all those public works jobs, and they put up a lot of good buildings and laboratories, so the facilities were much improved from what they were when I was in school.
And, well, everything had gotten
It really got bigger.
It just seemed like there was more students.
There were more students and more buildings and better buildings.
Larger curriculum maybe?
You mean college-wise, university-wise?
No, in the School of Vet Medicine.
I think curriculum was just about the same.
We didn't have enough teachers.
I know that.
Heck, I taught all kinds of courses there.
I taught a little of everything.
Not a little of everything, but I assisted many of them and taught courses for medicine and surgery that were not.
See, I came there in veterinary hygiene, what they called veterinary hygiene.

They had never had a department for that, and I had to work up something for that department, but I also taught non-infectious diseases for medicine and surgery and obstetrics, and I assisted with surgery, and I just filled in
where they needed.
You went into private practice in 1926.
Instead of going to work for the government, you went over to New Orleans.
That's right.
Why did you accept that job?
looking for some way to get enough money to eat, and they were looking for a man.
I guess Dr. Marsteller must have asked me if I wanted to go over there, and he loaned me $50 to get there on.
I didn't have any money.
So, yes.
So I went to New Orleans and was with that firm there, McLean, Carson, Dyke, and Chapman, for about four months, I guess.
Then I went to, Dr. Burns had been in Beaumont with Dr. Kerr, and he left to come to A&M, I guess, to teach.
And I guess he wrote me.
He wanted to know if I wanted to come there, and I did.
And so I worked for Dr. Kerr and became partner with him until I came to A&M in 1937.
Now when you were in private practice, basically what were your duties?
Were they small animals yet?
I did mostly the small animals, that is when I was with Dr. Kerr, mostly small animals and he did the large animals.
I stayed in the hospital, and he made the calls.
Because you were in an urban setting.
Was this the time when more and more people would bring in their house pets?
Yeah.
During the 1920s?
Yeah, well, it was picking up, yes.
That's right.
It was just, this is the time when house pets were starting to pick up.
Yeah, and then the crash came.
Yeah, yeah.
I'd like to talk about what was it like to be a veterinarian in private practice during the Great Depression?
It was tough going, and you did anything to get a little extra money.
One summer, I worked for the government on a drought relief program.
On what relief?
Drought relief.
They'd had a big drought down here in South Texas.
And I was down there buying cattle.
And then when I came back to Beaumont from that, when that job played out, I came back, of course, with Dr. Curry.
We stayed partners.
And I went to work for the city of Beaumont on meat and milk inspections.
And then after work hours, I'd go down to the hospital, and on Saturdays and Sundays, I'd work there at the hospital taking care of small animals, helping Dr. Kirk.
Were there a lot of people who just couldn't pay the bill?
Well, there were a lot of people that didn't pay their bill.
It was hard.
Yes, you had lots of debt accounts.
Did the number of small pets and small animals, because of the Depression, because it was so hard to get food, were the number of small animals declining?
Yes, it did decline.
And so your business in general then was probably declined.
Yeah, that's why I went to work for the city.
Yeah, right, right, right.
There wasn't enough there for both of us.
Your income then dropped.
Sure.
Of course, the money that, I was still a partner with Dr. Kerr, and what I got from the city, I went into the general pot there at the hospital.
Oh, really?
Oh, really?
And so you weren't full-time then?
I was full-time with the city, but I'd come after, at 5 o'clock, I'd go to the hospital and work there, and on Saturdays and Sundays.
Well, what were the duties of, your title was city veterinarian, wasn't it?
Yeah.
What were your duties there?
Well it was mostly, it was mostly milk hygiene, inspecting dairies and creameries, that sort of thing, and taking care of any problems there that turned up at the abattoir, the slaughterhouse, and
Well lots of times other things had come up.
I can remember one time they had a case of typhoid.
These people were isolated for typhoid and they couldn't pick up the milk bottles there.
So they had a room full of milk bottles when the thing was over.
So I had to go over there and supervise the disinfecting of all that stuff.
So different things that come up in the health department.
Yeah, I think that would broaden your background.
Oh yeah, it did.
And then in the evenings after you were done with that, then you'd go back to the veterinary hospital.
Yeah, and if there was anything to do, I'd take care of it.
How'd you get this Job City vet?
Well, they were looking for a man.
The one they had, let's see, Ward, T. Ward, I guess, left there.
He was the man just ahead of me.
And they were looking for a man, so I went over and talked to him about getting a job with him.
A man by the name of Cole was mayor then, had a lumber yard.
I went to talk to him, and then went to talk to the city manager.
They needed someone, so I got the job.
I tried to get it on a part-time basis, but they wanted a full-time man.
So, that's the way we did it.
In 1937, you were appointed head to a newly established department of veterinary and hygiene.
Why'd they pick you?
Well, there again, I don't know.
They were looking for a man for someone.
I can't tell you because Dr. Francis had died, and Dr. Marsteller was dean, and he'd gone to Europe, and they were looking for a man
And I guess Dr. Burns, Pat Burns, must have contacted me.
And I came up here and talked to him.
And I can't remember any other details.
I guess they sent me a, must have sent me a letter.
stating what my salary would be and whatnot and whatnot.
Why'd you take it?
Shoot, that was during the Depression.
Well, I know, but you had a job during the Depression.
Why'd you decide to change?
Well, we were splitting up down there.
There was two of us living off of that.
And there'd just be...
me and my wife living off of this and up here, so it looked like a better opportunity.
Were you rather nostalgic about the thought of coming back to Texas A&M?
Well, yes.
I loved the place, and I had kept up with it pretty well, had lots of friends here,
So I was glad to come back.
And here I'm still here.
Still in Bryan now.
I never go on the campus much anymore.
Too many people, too many automobiles.
And I don't really have any business up there, except visit.
I know very few people now.
So many new people have come in and there's been such a turnover that I've just lost my contacts out there to a large extent.
